repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
1. It's undefined to shift more than the width of the integer (except possibly on C++20 onwards?). This cases problems on MSVC when shifting exactly the width of the integer (#7089).

2. It's undefined to shift negative values. Practically I think this is OK in most of the real platforms we handle, so it might be worthwhile adding a few other known good special cases.

comment_data.body: This needs changing - rshift too far has a known answer so I may as well return that rather than falling back to Python
Shouldn't we move the special case before the general calculation? And let it end with `} else`?
Same here (preferably with an additional space after the `(long long)` cast, as you did for the `(long)` cast).

To make sure that we don't forget any platform specific boundaries, we could generate the test code for all positive and negative shifts that we optimise (and crossing the boundaries, e.g. -130…+130) and check the results for all of them, on all platforms, and that they are the same as in Python. Something like:
```cython
from operator import lshift as py_lshift

cdef compare_lshift(obj, shift, cython_result):
    py_result = py_lshift(obj, shift)
    assert cython_result == py_result, f"{obj} << {shift} == {cython_result} != {py_result}"

def integer_lshifts(obj):
    """
    >>> integer_lshifts(…)
    """
    …
    compare_lshift(obj, 1, obj << 1)
    compare_lshift(obj, 2, obj << 2)
    …
```

     """
     res = obj2 / 2
     return res
+
+
+def negative_rhs_lshift(obj: int):
+    """
+    >>> negative_rhs_lshift(5)
+    Traceback (most recent call last):
+        ...
+    ValueError: negative shift count
+    """
+    return (obj << (-1))
+
+def negative_rhs_rshift(obj: int):
+    """
+    >>> negative_rhs_rshift(5)
+    Traceback (most recent call last):
+        ...
+    ValueError: negative shift count
+    """
+    return (obj >> (-1))
+
+
+def big_lshift(obj):
+    """
+    >>> big_lshift(1)
+    1180591620717411303424
+    >>> big_lshift(-1)
+    -1180591620717411303424
+    """
+    return obj << 70
+
+def somewhat_big_lshift(obj):

comment_data.body: Yes. I moved it from a negative to a positive test and forgot to reverse the sign

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1210,6 +1210,21 @@ static {{c_ret_type}} __Pyx_Unpacked_{{cfunc_name}}(PyObject *op1, PyObject *op2
     const PY_LONG_LONG ll{{'a' if order == 'CObj' else 'b'}} = intval;
     PY_LONG_LONG ll{{ival}}, llx;
     {{endif}}
+    {{if op == 'Rshift' or op == 'Lshift'}}
+// shifting negative numbers is technically implementation defined on C, and
+// C++ before C++20. Most implementation do the right thing though so
+// special case ones we know are good.
+#if (defined(__cplusplus) && __cplusplus >= 202002L) \
+        || (defined(__GNUC__) || (defined(__clang__))) && \
+            (defined(__arm__) || defined(__x86_64__) || defined(__i386__)) \
+        || (defined(_MSC_VER) && \
+            /* _M_ARM is almost certainly fine, but disabled until we can test it */ \
+            (/*defined(_M_ARM) ||*/ defined(_M_AMD64) || defined(_M_IX86)))

commit.message:
Avoid and test some undefined behaviour in integer shifts

1. It's undefined to shift more than the width of the integer
   (except possibly on C++20 onwards?). This cases problems on
   MSVC when shifting exactly the width of the integer (#7089).

2. It's undefined to shift negative values. Practically I think
   this is OK in most of the real platforms we handle, so it
   might be worthwhile adding a few other known good special
   cases.
Fix spelling; add Windows ARM test
